title: We Got to Sesame Street | STUFF YOU SHOULD KNOW

talk about the origins of all this
because um Sesame Street and the whole
idea behind it grew out of two
developing things in the mid
1960s. One was President Lyndon Baines
Johnson's Great Society, which was this
um ideal policy movement toward ending
poverty and inequality, um getting rid
of crime, helping the environment,
making a great society. as far as
progressives were concerned. Um that was
one thing that was going on. So there
was much more of an awareness. There was
a lit like they literally declared a war
on poverty. Yeah. So there was much more
of an awareness of the a difference
between the advantaged and the
disadvantaged especially among children
in the United States at the time. And
then at the at the on the other side of
the coin, there was this growing
awareness among um psychologists and
other uh like educators that what had
been previously neglected and ignored,
which was the early childhood years, say
between three and five um were really
crucial to the intellectual development
of a kid. Yeah. And so there came this
idea to create television programming
and that was geared toward disadvantaged
kids between ages three and five to help
them to give them kind of a leg up
before they started schooling. That's
pretty much the premise of where this
whole thing came from. Yeah. Which is I
mean talk about a noble cause. They were
they were on board from the beginning
and we'll as you'll see you know shortly
uh they really put their money where

as far as the origin uh woman named Joan

maybe TV could educate kids. uh Cooney
was a in the newspaper biz. Um she
started producing TV and then as soon as
New York City got a um educational

and started working uh for them and I
think a a documentary on a Harlem

said in a documentary called Street Gang
I think colon how we got to Sesame
